desc: North Korean forces cross the 38th parallel, starting the Korean War.
The 'Peanuts' comic strip by Charles M. Schulz is first published.
President Truman announces the development of the hydrogen bomb.
Two Puerto Rican nationalists attempt to assassinate Harry S. Truman.
Senator Joseph McCarthy claims to have a list of communists in the State Department.
The 'Declaration of Conscience' is delivered by Senator Margaret Chase Smith.
The Great Brink's Robbery occurs in Boston, with over $2.7 million stolen.
The first broadcast of Radio Free Europe takes place.
The FCC issues the first license for color television to CBS.
First jet-to-jet dogfight in history occurs over North Korea.
President Truman relieves General Douglas MacArthur of his command.
The first episode of 'I Love Lucy' premieres on CBS.
The 22nd Amendment is ratified, limiting Presidents to two terms.
UNIVAC I, the first commercial computer, is dedicated at the Census Bureau.
The first transcontinental live television broadcast takes place.
Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage.
The Treaty of Paris is signed, establishing the European Coal and Steel Community.
Bobby Thomson hits the 'Shot Heard 'Round the World' to win the NL pennant.
The EBR-I in Idaho becomes the first nuclear reactor to generate electricity.
The racial integration of the U.S. Army begins in Korea.
Dwight D. Eisenhower is elected President in a landslide victory.
Elizabeth II becomes Queen upon the death of her father, George VI.
The U.S. detonates the first hydrogen bomb, 'Ivy Mike,' in the Pacific.
The keel is laid for the USS Nautilus, the first nuclear submarine.
Richard Nixon delivers his famous 'Checkers speech' on television.
The Sun Studios in Memphis begins its first recording sessions.
The first successful mechanical heart surgery is performed by Dr. Forest Dodrill.
The Great Smog of London begins, killing thousands in days.
The first landing of an aircraft at the North Pole is made by U.S. pilots.
The 1952 Summer Olympics open in Helsinki, Finland.
The Korean Armistice Agreement is signed, ending active combat.
Soviet leader Joseph Stalin dies after 30 years in power.
Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay reach the summit of Mt. Everest.
Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are executed at Sing Sing Prison.
The first issue of Playboy magazine is published.
Operation Ajax: A CIA-backed coup overthrows the Prime Minister of Iran.
Crick and Watson publish their paper on the structure of DNA.
The first televised presidential inauguration takes place (Eisenhower).
Eisenhower signs NSC 162/2, formalizing the 'New Look' defense policy.
Soviet troops crush an uprising of workers in East Berlin.
Brown v. Board of Education: Supreme Court outlaws school segregation.
The Army-McCarthy hearings begin their televised broadcast.
The first nuclear-powered submarine, the USS Nautilus, is launched.
The Geneva Accords partition Vietnam into North and South.
The Algerian War of Independence begins against French rule.
Roger Bannister becomes the first person to run a mile in under 4 minutes.
The world's first nuclear power plant (Obninsk) opens in the USSR.
The first documented case of a human (Ann Hodges) being hit by a meteorite.
U.S. detonates 'Castle Bravo,' its largest ever nuclear test, at Bikini Atoll.
Senator Joseph McCarthy is formally censured by the U.S. Senate.
Rosa Parks is arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat.
Disneyland opens its doors in Anaheim, California.
The Salk polio vaccine is declared safe and effective for public use.
Actor James Dean dies in a car crash at the age of 24.
The Warsaw Pact is signed by eight communist nations.
Physicist Albert Einstein dies at the age of 76.
Emmett Till is murdered in Mississippi, sparking national outrage.
The 24 Hours of Le Mans disaster kills 83 spectators.
Ngô Đình Diệm proclaims himself President of the Republic of Vietnam.
U.S. begins training the South Vietnamese Army.
Eisenhower signs the Federal Aid Highway Act, creating the Interstates.
The Suez Crisis begins as Israel invades the Sinai Peninsula.
Elvis Presley makes his first appearance on The Ed Sullivan Show.
Eisenhower is re-elected for a second term.
Grace Kelly marries Prince Rainier III of Monaco.
Khrushchev delivers his 'Secret Speech' denouncing Stalin's crimes.
The Hungarian Revolution begins against Soviet-backed policies.
The first transatlantic telephone cable (TAT-1) begins operation.
Finland regains the Porkkala naval base from the Soviet Union.
Tunisia gains independence from France.
The USSR launches Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite.
The Little Rock Nine integrate Central High School under federal guard.
The Treaty of Rome is signed, establishing the EEC.
Sputnik 2 is launched with Laika the dog, the first animal in orbit.
U.S. launch attempt of Vanguard TV3 fails on national television.
The Eisenhower Doctrine is announced, offering aid to Middle East allies.
Windscale fire in the UK becomes the world's first major nuclear accident.
Hurricane Audrey strikes Louisiana, killing over 400 people.
The first color TV broadcast of a feature film (The Wizard of Oz) occurs.
Malaya (now Malaysia) gains independence from the UK.
Explorer 1, the first U.S. satellite, successfully reaches orbit.
NASA is created by the signing of the National Aeronautics and Space Act.
Pan Am makes the first commercial transatlantic jet flight (Boeing 707).
Operation Blue Bat: U.S. Marines land in Lebanon to support the government.
The Second Taiwan Strait Crisis begins with the shelling of Quemoy.
The European Economic Community (Common Market) officially begins.
Egypt and Syria form the United Arab Republic.
Former Hungarian PM Imre Nagy is executed for his role in the 1956 uprising.
The current Constitution of France (Fifth Republic) is adopted.
Jack Kilby demonstrates the first integrated circuit at Texas Instruments.
Fulgencio Batista flees Cuba as Fidel Castro's revolution succeeds.
'The Day the Music Died': Buddy Holly dies in a plane crash.
Alaska is admitted as the 49th state of the Union.
Hawaii is admitted as the 50th state of the Union.
The 'Kitchen Debate' takes place between Nixon and Khrushchev in Moscow.
The first episode of 'The Twilight Zone' premieres on CBS.
The Dalai Lama flees Tibet for India following an uprising.
The USS George Washington, the first ballistic missile sub, is launched.
The Soviet Luna 2 becomes the first man-made object to reach the moon.
The Declaration of the Rights of the Child is adopted by the UN.
The first televised presidential debate takes place between Kennedy and Nixon.
John F. Kennedy defeats Richard Nixon in one of the closest elections in U.S. history.
An American U-2 spy plane is shot down over the Soviet Union.
The Greensboro sit-ins begin at a Woolworth's lunch counter.
The FDA approves the first birth control pill for commercial use.
The bathyscaphe Trieste reaches the bottom of the Mariana Trench.
OPEC is founded at a Baghdad conference by five oil-producing nations.
Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev famously pounds his shoe on a table at the UN.
Joseph Kittinger makes the highest parachute jump in history (102,800 feet).
The first weather satellite, TIROS-1, is launched by the United States.
Construction begins on the Berlin Wall to stop defections to the West.
The CIA-backed Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba begins and fails.
The first Freedom Riders depart Washington D.C. for the Deep South.
John F. Kennedy is inaugurated as the 35th President of the United States.
Alan Shepard becomes the first American in space aboard Freedom 7.
The SL-1 experimental nuclear reactor in Idaho explodes, killing three operators.
The Soviet Union detonates the Tsar Bomba, the most powerful nuclear weapon ever.
Congolese leader Patrice Lumumba is assassinated with Belgian and U.S. involvement.
Sierra Leone gains independence from the United Kingdom.
The world's first theme park, Six Flags Over Texas, officially opens.
The Cuban Missile Crisis brings the world to the brink of nuclear war.
John Glenn becomes the first American to orbit the Earth.
Riots occur as James Meredith becomes the first Black student at Ole Miss.
Marilyn Monroe is found dead in her Los Angeles home.
Rachel Carson's 'Silent Spring' is published, sparking the environmental movement.
Telstar 1, the first active communications satellite, is launched into orbit.
President Kennedy signs an executive order ending racial bias in federal housing.
Marilyn Monroe sings 'Happy Birthday, Mr. President' at Madison Square Garden.
Algeria gains independence from France after an eight-year war.
Three inmates (including Frank Morris) escape from Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary.
President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, Texas.
Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his 'I Have a Dream' speech at the March on Washington.
The 16th Street Baptist Church bombing kills four young girls in Birmingham.
Lee Harvey Oswald is shot and killed by Jack Ruby on live television.
Governor George Wallace stands in the schoolhouse door to block integration.
The USS Thresher nuclear submarine sinks during deep-dive trials, killing 129.
Civil rights leader Medgar Evers is assassinated outside his home in Mississippi.
The first episode of 'The Fugitive' premieres on ABC.
Valentina Tereshkova becomes the first woman to travel into space.
South Vietnamese President Ngô Đình Diệm is overthrown and executed in a coup.
The Beatles perform on The Ed Sullivan Show, launching British Invasion.
President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
Congress passes the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, escalating the Vietnam War.
President Johnson declares a 'War on Poverty' in his State of the Union address.
Lyndon B. Johnson defeats Barry Goldwater in a landslide presidential victory.
The Good Friday Earthquake, the strongest in U.S. history, hits Alaska.
Civil rights workers Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner are murdered in Mississippi.
The first U.S. Surgeon General's report on smoking and health is released.
Martin Luther King Jr. is announced as the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.
The Philadelphia race riot begins, lasting for several days.
President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
'Bloody Sunday': Police attack civil rights marchers in Selma, Alabama.
Malcolm X is assassinated at the Audubon Ballroom in Harlem.
The Watts Riots erupt in Los Angeles following a traffic stop.
President Johnson signs the Social Security Act, creating Medicare and Medicaid.
The Great Northeast Blackout leaves 30 million people without power.
Operation Rolling Thunder begins a massive bombing campaign in Vietnam.
The first episode of 'The Soupy Sales Show' premieres nationally.
The Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 is signed at the Statue of Liberty.
Edward White becomes the first American to perform a spacewalk (Gemini 4).
The first episode of 'Star Trek' premieres on NBC.
The Supreme Court issues its ruling in Miranda v. Arizona (Miranda Rights).
The Black Panther Party is founded in Oakland by Newton and Seale.
The National Organization for Women (NOW) is founded.
Ronald Reagan is elected Governor of California.
Charles Whitman kills 14 people from the clock tower at UT Austin.
Chairman Mao launches the Cultural Revolution in China.
The Soviet Union launches Luna 10, the first spacecraft to orbit the moon.
The first public 'Acid Test' is held in San Francisco by the Merry Pranksters.
Walt Disney dies from complications related to lung cancer.
The first Super Bowl is played between Green Bay and Kansas City.
Loving v. Virginia strikes down laws banning interracial marriage.
The 'Summer of Love' reaches its peak in San Francisco.
The Six-Day War is fought between Israel and its Arab neighbors.
Thurgood Marshall is sworn in as the first Black Supreme Court Justice.
A flash fire during a launch pad test kills the crew of Apollo 1.
Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his 'Beyond Vietnam' anti-war speech.
Carl Stokes is elected Mayor of Cleveland, first Black mayor of a major city.
Sweden switches from driving on the left to driving on the right ('Dagen H').
Dr. Christiaan Barnard performs the world's first human heart transplant.
Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.
Robert F. Kennedy is assassinated in Los Angeles after winning CA primary.
The Tet Offensive begins, turning U.S. public opinion against the Vietnam War.
Riots erupt outside the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
Tommie Smith and John Carlos give the Black Power salute at the Olympics.
The USS Pueblo is attacked and seized by North Korean forces.
U.S. soldiers kill hundreds of unarmed civilians in the My Lai Massacre.
The crew of Apollo 8 becomes the first humans to orbit the moon.
Shirley Chisholm becomes the first Black woman elected to the U.S. Congress.
The news program '60 Minutes' premieres on CBS.
Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin become the first humans to walk on the moon.
The Woodstock Music and Art Fair is held in Bethel, New York.
The Stonewall Riots begin in NYC, sparking the LGBTQ+ rights movement.
Followers of Charles Manson murder Sharon Tate and four others.
'Sesame Street' premieres on NET (now PBS).
Senator Ted Kennedy is involved in a car accident at Chappaquiddick.
The first message is sent over ARPANET, the precursor to the internet.
Richard Nixon is inaugurated as the 37th President of the United States.
Violence erupts at the Altamont Free Concert during a Rolling Stones set.
Former President and WWII General Dwight D. Eisenhower dies at age 78.
The Kent State shootings occur as National Guardsmen fire on anti-war protesters.
The first Earth Day is celebrated by millions of Americans.
An oxygen tank explodes on Apollo 13 ('Houston, we have a problem').
Rock legend Jimi Hendrix dies in London at the age of 27.
Paul McCartney announces the official break-up of The Beatles.
The Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act is signed, banning TV tobacco ads.
The 'Kudirka incident' occurs: a Lithuanian sailor unsuccessfully attempts to defect to a US Coast Guard ship.
The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty officially enters into force.
Angela Davis is arrested in New York City after a nationwide search.
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) officially begins operations.
The New York Times begins publishing excerpts from the Pentagon Papers.
Walt Disney World opens its doors in Orlando, Florida.
The 26th Amendment is ratified, lowering the voting age to 18.
Jim Morrison, lead singer of The Doors, dies in Paris.
The ban on radio and television cigarette advertisements takes effect.
The 'Nixon Shock': The US unilaterally ends the direct convertibility of the US dollar to gold.
The Attica Prison riot occurs in New York, resulting in 43 deaths.
Intel releases the 4004, the world's first single-chip microprocessor.
A man known as D.B. Cooper hijacks a plane and parachutes out with $200,000.
The NASDAQ stock market index begins its first day of operation.
Five men are arrested for the break-in at the Watergate complex in D.C.
Richard Nixon arrives in China, the first US president to visit the PRC.
The Munich Massacre: Palestinian terrorists attack Israeli athletes at the Olympics.
Richard Nixon defeats George McGovern in a massive electoral landslide.
Apollo 17 launches, the final mission of the Apollo lunar program.
Governor George Wallace is shot and paralyzed during a campaign stop in Maryland.
Bloody Sunday: British paratroopers shoot civil rights protesters in Northern Ireland.
Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571 crashes in the Andes (survivors resort to cannibalism).
Bobby Fischer defeats Boris Spassky to become the first American World Chess Champion.
Title IX is signed into law, prohibiting sex discrimination in federally funded education.
The Supreme Court issues its landmark decision in Roe v. Wade.
The last U.S. combat troops leave South Vietnam.
OPEC begins an oil embargo against the U.S. and other nations.
The World Trade Center in New York City is officially dedicated.
Vice President Spiro Agnew resigns amid federal tax evasion charges.
The 'Saturday Night Massacre': Nixon fires special prosecutor Archibald Cox.
Skylab, the first US space station, is launched into orbit.
The first handheld cellular phone call is made by Martin Cooper of Motorola.
A military coup in Chile overthrows President Salvador Allende.
The Paris Peace Accords are signed, establishing a ceasefire in Vietnam.
Richard Nixon announces his resignation as President of the United States.
President Gerald Ford grants Richard Nixon a full and unconditional pardon.
Heiress Patty Hearst is kidnapped by the Symbionese Liberation Army.
The 'Rumble in the Jungle': Muhammad Ali knocks out George Foreman.
Hank Aaron hits his 715th home run, breaking Babe Ruth's record.
The skeleton of 'Lucy,' a 3.2-million-year-old hominid, is discovered in Ethiopia.
'Smiling Buddha': India successfully detonates its first nuclear weapon.
The first commercial use of a UPC barcode occurs at a Marsh supermarket in Ohio.
President Ford announces a conditional amnesty program for Vietnam draft dodgers.
Mariner 10 becomes the first spacecraft to fly by the planet Mercury.
The Fall of Saigon marks the end of the Vietnam War.
Apollo-Soyuz Test Project: US and Soviet spacecraft dock in orbit.
Patty Hearst is captured by the FBI after over a year on the run.
Saturday Night Live (originally Saturday Night) premieres on NBC.
Spanish dictator Francisco Franco dies after 36 years in power.
Microsoft is founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen in Albuquerque.
President Gerald Ford survives two separate assassination attempts in 17 days.
The game show 'Wheel of Fortune' premieres on NBC.
Labor leader Jimmy Hoffa disappears from a restaurant in Detroit.
The Helsinki Accords are signed, attempting to improve relations between the West and Communists.
The United States celebrates its Bicentennial with massive festivities.
Jimmy Carter defeats Gerald Ford in the presidential election.
Mao Zedong, the founding father of the People's Republic of China, dies.
The Viking 1 lander becomes the first spacecraft to land successfully on Mars.
The Concorde begins its first commercial supersonic flights.
Apple Computer Company is founded by Jobs, Wozniak, and Wayne.
The Chowchilla kidnapping: a school bus with 26 children is buried underground.
The Soweto Uprising begins in South Africa against apartheid education.
The Supreme Court rules in Gregg v. Georgia that the death penalty is constitutional.
First known case of Ebola virus disease occurs in Zaire (now Congo).
The film 'Star Wars' premieres, changing the movie industry forever.
Elvis Presley is found dead at his Graceland estate in Memphis.
A massive blackout hits New York City, leading to widespread looting.
President Jimmy Carter pardons most Vietnam War draft evaders.
The Tenerife airport disaster: two 747s collide, killing 583 people.
The Torrijos-Carter Treaties are signed, planning the transfer of the Panama Canal.
The Apple II, one of the first successful personal computers, is released.
The 'Wow! signal' is received by the Big Ear radio telescope.
Anwar Sadat becomes the first Arab leader to officially visit Israel.
Voyager 1 is launched to study the outer Solar System.
The Camp David Accords are signed by Israel and Egypt.
The Jonestown Massacre: over 900 members of the People's Temple die.
Louise Brown, the first 'test tube baby,' is born in England.
Harvey Milk and Mayor George Moscone are assassinated in San Francisco.
California voters pass Proposition 13, significantly cutting property taxes.
Karol Wojtyła is elected Pope John Paul II.
The first Unabomber attack occurs at Northwestern University.
President Carter declares a federal emergency at Love Canal.
Serial killer Ted Bundy is captured for the final time in Florida.
Soviet satellite Kosmos 954 crashes in northern Canada, spreading radiation.
The Iran Hostage Crisis begins as students seize the US embassy in Tehran.
A partial nuclear meltdown occurs at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania.
Margaret Thatcher becomes the first female Prime Minister of the UK.
The U.S. and China officially establish full diplomatic relations.
The Soviet Union invades Afghanistan to support a communist government.
Sony introduces the Walkman, the first portable cassette player.
The SALT II treaty is signed by Carter and Brezhnev in Vienna.
President Jimmy Carter delivers his 'Malaise Speech' (Crisis of Confidence).
Lord Mountbatten is killed by an IRA bomb on his boat in Ireland.
The Vela Incident: A mysterious 'double flash' is detected near South Africa.
Former Beatle John Lennon is shot and killed outside his home in New York City.
Mount St. Helens erupts in Washington state, killing 57 people.
Ronald Reagan defeats Jimmy Carter in a landslide presidential election.
The 'Miracle on Ice': The U.S. Olympic hockey team defeats the Soviet Union.
CNN (Cable News Network) launches as the first 24-hour news station.
Operation Eagle Claw: A mission to rescue hostages in Iran ends in a fatal crash.
Lech Wałęsa leads the shipyard strike in Gdańsk, forming the Solidarity union.
Over 350 million people tune in to the TV show 'Dallas' to find out 'Who Shot J.R.?'
The Iran-Iraq War begins as Iraqi forces invade western Iran.
President Carter announces a U.S. boycott of the Summer Olympics in Moscow.
President Ronald Reagan is shot and wounded by John Hinckley Jr.
MTV (Music Television) launches, playing 'Video Killed the Radio Star' first.
Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer are married at St Paul's Cathedral.
Iran releases 52 American hostages minutes after Reagan's inauguration.
Sandra Day O'Connor is nominated as the first female Supreme Court Justice.
PATCO air traffic controllers go on strike; Reagan fires 11,359 of them.
The CDC reports the first cases of what would later be identified as AIDS.
The first Space Shuttle mission, Columbia (STS-1), is launched.
Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated during a victory parade.
Operation Opera: Israel destroys Iraq's Osirak nuclear reactor in an airstrike.
The Vietnam Veterans Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C.
The Falklands War begins as Argentina invades the British territory.
The Tylenol murders begin in Chicago, leading to tamper-evident packaging.
Sony releases the first commercial Compact Disc (CD) player.
One million people demonstrate in Central Park against nuclear weapons.
The Senate passes a bill that makes it a crime to reveal the identity of covert agents.
Barney Clark becomes the first person to receive a permanent artificial heart.
Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev dies and is succeeded by Yuri Andropov.
AT&T agrees to break up its monopoly, forming the 'Baby Bells.'
The Lebanon War begins as Israeli forces invade southern Lebanon.
Sally Ride becomes the first American woman to travel into space.
A suicide truck bomb destroys the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut, killing 241.
Soviet jets shoot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007, killing 269 people.
President Reagan proposes the Strategic Defense Initiative ('Star Wars').
U.S. forces invade Grenada to depose the military council (Operation Urgent Fury).
Soviet officer Stanislav Petrov prevents a nuclear war by ignoring a false alarm.
The ARPANET officially switches to TCP/IP, marking the birth of the Internet.
Reagan signs a bill creating Martin Luther King Jr. Day as a federal holiday.
Pioneer 10 becomes the first man-made object to leave the central Solar System.
The TV movie 'The Day After' airs, depicting a full-scale nuclear war.
Apple Computer introduces the Macintosh with its iconic '1984' TV ad.
The Summer Olympics open in Los Angeles, boycotted by the Soviet Union.
Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is assassinated by her bodyguards.
Reagan defeats Walter Mondale, winning 49 out of 50 states.
The Bhopal gas tragedy in India kills thousands in a pesticide plant leak.
Geraldine Ferraro is chosen as the first female VP candidate for a major party.
A suicide car bomb attacks the U.S. Embassy annex in East Beirut.
The Soviet Union announces it will boycott the Los Angeles Summer Olympics.
Bruce McCandless II performs the first untethered spacewalk using the MMU.
Bernie Goetz shoots four youths on a New York City subway train.
The Live Aid concerts are held in London and Philadelphia to raise money for famine.
The wreck of the RMS Titanic is discovered by a joint French-American expedition.
Mikhail Gorbachev becomes leader of the Soviet Union, beginning an era of reform.
Microsoft releases Windows 1.0, its first graphical operating environment.
Scientists from the British Antarctic Survey announce the discovery of the ozone hole.
TWA Flight 847 is hijacked by Lebanese terrorists; the ordeal lasts 17 days.
Palestinian terrorists hijack the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.
Reagan and Gorbachev meet for the first time at the Geneva Summit.
The Coca-Cola Company introduces 'New Coke,' resulting in a massive backlash.
Actor Rock Hudson becomes the first major celebrity to die from AIDS.
The Space Shuttle Challenger explodes 73 seconds after liftoff.
The Chernobyl nuclear disaster occurs in the Ukrainian Soviet Republic.
The Iran-Contra affair is first publicly revealed by a Lebanese magazine.
The Statue of Liberty is rededicated on its centennial after a massive renovation.
The People Power Revolution in the Philippines deposes Ferdinand Marcos.
The U.S. bombs Libya (Operation El Dorado Canyon) in retaliation for a Berlin disco bombing.
The Reykjavík Summit between Reagan and Gorbachev ends without a deal.
The Voyager aircraft becomes the first to fly non-stop around the world without refueling.
The 'Big Bang' deregulation of the London Stock Exchange occurs.
The cargo ship Khian Sea leaves Philadelphia with toxic ash, beginning a 2-year odyssey.
'Black Monday': The stock market crashes, with the Dow dropping over 22%.
Reagan challenges Gorbachev at the Brandenburg Gate: 'Tear down this wall!'
The INF Treaty is signed, eliminating an entire class of nuclear missiles.
The world watches the rescue of 'Baby Jessica' from a well in Texas.
Televangelist Jim Bakker resigns from the PTL Club amid a sex scandal.
The USS Stark is hit by two Exocet missiles from an Iraqi jet, killing 37.
West German pilot Mathias Rust lands his Cessna in Red Square, Moscow.
Supernova 1987A is observed, the first naked-eye supernova since 1604.
The world population is estimated to have reached five billion people.
The FCC abolishes the Fairness Doctrine regarding political broadcasts.
Pan Am Flight 103 is destroyed by a bomb over Lockerbie, Scotland.
George H.W. Bush defeats Michael Dukakis in the presidential election.
Al-Qaeda is formed by Osama bin Laden during a meeting in Pakistan.
The Space Shuttle program resumes with the launch of Discovery (STS-26).
The USS Vincennes shoots down Iran Air Flight 655, killing all 290 aboard.
The Morris Worm, the first major computer worm, is released on the internet.
The Ramstein air show disaster in West Germany kills 70 people.
NASA scientist James Hansen testifies to Congress that global warming has begun.
The Geneva Accords are signed, setting a timetable for Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan.
Saddam Hussein's forces carry out a chemical weapons attack on the city of Halabja.
The Berlin Wall is opened, allowing citizens to cross freely for the first time.
The Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are crushed by the Chinese military.
The Exxon Valdez oil spill occurs in Prince William Sound, Alaska.
The Loma Prieta earthquake hits the San Francisco Bay Area during the World Series.
Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceaușescu is executed during a violent revolution.
The U.S. invades Panama (Operation Just Cause) to depose Manuel Noriega.
Emperor Hirohito of Japan dies, ending the 62-year Shōwa era.
Ayatollah Khomeini issues a fatwa calling for the death of author Salman Rushdie.
Tadeusz Mazowiecki becomes the first non-communist Prime Minister in the Eastern Bloc.
United Airlines Flight 232 crashes in Sioux City, Iowa; 184 survive.
